Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Reoperation Techniques for Mitral Valve Repair Failure

Participants.evidence: 11 patients with moderately severe or severe mitral regurgitation due to recurrent prolapse after initial posterior leaflet repair with artificial chordae and annuloplasty, from January 1, 2008, to January 31, 2023.

Intervention.evidence: Re-repair techniques included creation of new, shorter artificial chordae (n=5), posterior leaflet resection (n=5), and placement of a new annuloplasty (n=8).

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the outcomes of different reoperation techniques for mitral valve repair failure.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the degree of mitral regurgitation post-reoperation, evaluated by echocardiogram at discharge and follow-up (median 20 months).

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 11 patients, 10 underwent mitral valve re-repair, and one had valve replacement.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 11 patients, 10 underwent mitral valve re-repair, and one had valve replacement.

Result_Outcome.evidence: All patients left the operating room with no or trace mitral regurgitation, confirmed on predischarge echocardiogram. At last follow-up, all patients had mild MR or less.

Harms.evidence: There was no operative mortality or major complications.
